author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Meeting 116-Year-Old Edith Ceccarelli, the Oldest Person in America
description: Ceccarelli, who lives in California’s redwood country, is the 29th person ever recorded to reach 116.
content: Edith Ceccarelli, done up in pearl earrings and a silk shawl, rested in an easy chair next to her birthday cake, adorned with the number 116.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Super Bowl Viewership Rose to 123.4 Million, a Record High
description: The figure easily exceeded last year’s 115.1 million, capping off a big year for N.F.L. ratings.
content: Sunday night’s overtime Super Bowl shattered ratings records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Karoun Demirjian
title: A bill with $14 billion for Israel’s war in Gaza passes the Senate but may falter in the House.
description: A $95 billion foreign aid package passed by the Senate on Tuesday morning includes $14.1 billion for Israel’s war against Hamas, though the bill still faces uncertainty in the House.
content: A $95 billion foreign aid package passed by the Senate on Tuesday morning includes $14.1 billion for Israel’s war against Hamas, though the bill still faces uncertainty in the House.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘The Middle of a Post-Divorce Breakdown’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: “Hello?” Mom repeated into the phone. The caller began singing his college fraternity song. It had been almost 70 years since she was crowned Alpha Phi Alpha’s “Sweetheart” at Howard University. Widowed and living alone, Mom couldn’t place the song and had forgotten it was Valentine’s Day. Dinner dishes sat in the sink. News blared from the T.V. He sang into the second stanza before she remembered those “Sweetheart” years when she felt revered and cherished. Mom finally recognized her friend’s voice. He said he was blind now. “You can still carry a tune,” she replied, smiling. I smiled too. — Lisa Argrette Ahmad
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: Cook as if You’re in a Rom-Com
description: Now is the time to trot out special-occasion classics like rib-eye steak, rosemary rack of lamb and — spoons ready — vanilla crème brûlée.
content: It’s the third act. After an adorable meet-cute and some bumbling mishaps, our romantic leads — you and your valentine — have finally found each other. The lighting is warm, the wine is open and Aaron Neville’s “Crazy Love” is playing softly in the background. It’s time for dinner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Was Boston’s Snow Forecast a Bust? Depends on Whom You Ask.
description: The original forecast called for a foot of snow in Boston, but now totals might be less than half that amount, a National Weather Service meteorologist said.
content: The quick-moving winter storm sweeping across the Northeast was once poised to blanket the Boston area with up to a foot of snow but will now push farther south than expected, cutting snowfall totals in the region by more than half than expected earlier, according to the latest estimates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Bob Moore, Who Founded Bob’s Red Mill, Is Dead at 94
description: A former gas station owner, he was learning to read the Bible in its original languages when he changed course and started what became an artisanal-grains powerhouse.
content: Bob Moore, the grandfatherly entrepreneur who, with his wife, Charlee, leveraged an image of organic heartiness and wholesome Americana to turn the artisanal grain company Bob’s Red Mill into a $100 million-a-year business, died on Saturday at his home in Milwaukie, Ore. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Two Students, Two Views, One Campus Conflict in the Midwest
description: At the University of Michigan, a Palestinian activist and a self-described Zionist counterprotester have little in common, except the way they were shaped by life on campus.
content: They represent opposite corners at the University of Michigan, two sides of student activism who have hunkered down and almost never communicate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Vanessa Friedman
title: Tiger Woods Introduces His New Brand: Sun Day Red
description: Mr. Woods is trading in the Nike swoosh he wore for decades for the tiger logo of Sun Day Red, which will be a stand-alone unit within TaylorMade Golf.
content: For even those who have only a passing interest in golf, one of the sport’s most memorable images is of Tiger Woods playing his way to another major tournament victory while wearing a red polo shirt with a white Nike swoosh.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: If You Don’t Want Valentines, There’s Always Sweet Revenge
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, February 14, 2024.
content: “The visual image of him getting eaten by a Komodo dragon is pretty satisfying.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: A Downtown Darling Says Farewell. Does It Matter?
description: On Puppets and Puppets’ last New York Fashion Week show.
content: On Monday, Puppets and Puppets, the six-year-old New York fashion brand/art project, had its last show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: Usher Gets Married After the Super Bowl
description: After an electric halftime show, the R&B star and his girlfriend, Jennifer Goicoechea, tied the knot at a chapel in Las Vegas.
content: It’s been a big week for Usher. After delivering a dynamic halftime performance at the Super Bowl, the R&B star married his partner, Jennifer Jean Goicoechea, in Las Vegas on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Kelvin Kiptum, Marathon World Record-Holder, Is Dead at 24
description: Kiptum, who came tantalizingly close last year to breaching the mythical two-hour barrier in the marathon, was killed in a car accident in Kenya.
content: Kelvin Kiptum, who shattered the world record in the men’s marathon last year, finishing tantalizingly close to the mythical and once unfathomable two-hour barrier, died in a car crash on Sunday in Kaptagat in western Kenya. He was 24.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 13, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Feb. 13, 2024.
content: An article on Monday about the Republican Party’s efforts to regain influence in New York City suburbs misstated the location of a Republican rally in Massapequa in Nassau County, N.Y. It was held at an American Legion hall, not a V.F.W. hall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: What’s Your TV ‘Comfort Food’?
description: “Gilmore Girls”? “Friends”? “NCIS”? What show do you turn to when you are stressed, tired or just need a lift? Why?
content: Is there a TV show you regularly watch when you’re stressed, tired or in need of comfort? Why do you think it soothes you?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Upgraded’ Review: Faking It That She’s Made It
description: Camila Mendes plays a broke assistant posing as an art world bigwig in this slyly charming romantic comedy.
content: Good artists copy; great artists steal. I coined that — OK, Picasso supposedly did. But the maxim may as well be stamped across the forehead of Ana Santos (Camila Mendes), a broke, harried auction house assistant who, after scoring a major work trip to London, falls into posing as an art world V.I.P.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Did You Keep a Money Secret, and Have a Happy Outcome? Tell Us About It.
description: If you or someone you love hid a financial matter that ended well, The Times would like to hear from you.
content: It’s not unusual to hear tales of people keeping family members or friends in the dark about aspects of their finances — debt from credit cards or gambling losses, for example — and how those issues caused problems in a relationship or within a family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Democrats Flip Santos’s House Seat in Early Election-Year Test
description: The victory by Tom Suozzi, an ex-congressman, offers his party a potential path in November as it contests suburban swing districts like this one.
content: Tom Suozzi, a former Democratic congressman, won a closely watched special House election in New York on Tuesday, narrowing the Republican majority in Washington and offering his party a potential playbook to run in key suburban swing areas in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Muktita Suhartono, Sui-Lee Wee and Hasya Nindita
title: A ‘Democracy Party’ Like No Other: One of the World’s Biggest Elections
description: The celebration of the act of casting a vote has particular resonance in Indonesia, which until a few decades ago was a brutal dictatorship.
content: The young women and men moved from booth to booth, asking questions about the political hopefuls’ track records and visions for the country. A few steps away, first-time voters practiced casting their ballots in pretend voting booths. And onstage, talk show guests discussed how to make an informed choice in backing a candidate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: New York Braces for Snow; Trump’s Last-Ditch Immunity Effort
description: Plus, who will replace George Santos?
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan and Olivia Bensimon
title: Woman, 74, Killed by Falling Bricks While Shoveling Her Brooklyn Stoop
description: Dale Singer was on the steps of her home Tuesday afternoon when a portion of the facade suddenly collapsed on her, security camera footage showed.
content: A 74-year-old Brooklyn woman was killed on Tuesday when a portion of her Sunset Park home’s facade crashed down on her while she was shoveling snow off her stoop, according to officials and video footage from a security camera at a nearby business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Scott McIntyre
title: Roses Are Red, Violets Are Blue, Through Miami’s Airport Yours Probably Flew
description: About 90 percent of the cut flowers imported to the United States each year, including millions of Valentine’s Day roses, enter the country through Miami International Airport.
content: The roses that you buy this week from a florist, supermarket or website for Valentine’s Day in all likelihood arrived in the United States through one place: Miami International Airport, the port of entry for about 90 percent of the nation’s imported cut flowers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: What New Love Does to Your Brain
description: Roses are red, violets are blue. Romance can really mess with you.
content: New love can consume our thoughts, supercharge our emotions and, on occasion, cause us to act out of character.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nia Decaille
title: What Is Black Love Day?
description: On Feb. 13, 1993, Ayo Handy-Kendi, a community organizer and native of Washington, D.C., created the holiday to celebrate communal love and pride in being “unapologetically Black.”
content: While Feb. 13 is not a federal holiday, a deeply meaningful celebration rooted in the Black community exists: Black Love Day. The first Black Love Day was established on Feb. 13, 1993, when Ayo Handy-Kendi, a spiritual community organizer, felt compelled by a higher power to bring her community together, she said in an interview with The New York Times. The first sign came on New Year’s Eve in 1992 after she saw Spike Lee’s film “Malcolm X,” which follows the life of the civil rights leader of the same name, portrayed by Denzel Washington. On the bus ride home, she said, she reflected on the assassination of Malcolm X and heard a voice — “the creator”— speak to her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Franz Lidz
title: Who Kissed First? Archaeology Has an Answer.
description: A married pair of researchers have “set the record straight” on the ancient history of smooching.
content: This is a love story: During the spring of 2008, long before they produced evidence of humanity’s first recorded kiss, Sophie Lund Rasmussen and Troels Pank Arboll clasped lips in their first good-night snog. They met a week earlier at a pub near the University of Copenhagen, where both were undergraduates. “I had asked my cousin if he knew any nice single guys with long hair and long beards,” Dr. Rasmussen said. “And he said, ‘Sure, I’ll introduce you to one.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Trump Is Losing It
description: Unfortunately for Biden, the former president benefits from something akin to the soft bigotry of low expectations.
content: It is unclear whether Donald Trump has forgotten the precise nature of NATO or whether he ever fully grasped it in the first place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: House Republicans Impeach Mayorkas for Border Policies
description: In a redo of their first failed attempt, Republicans pushed through the charges over solid Democratic opposition, making the homeland security secretary the first sitting cabinet member to be impeached.
content: The United States House of Representatives voted narrowly on Tuesday to impeach Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, in a precedent-shattering vote that charged him with willfully refusing to enforce border laws and breaching the public trust.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Meet the Woman Who Helped Pay for That R.F.K. Super Bowl Ad
description: Nicole Shanahan, a Bay Area lawyer once married to the Google co-founder Sergey Brin, gave $4 million and creative guidance to a group backing Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s independent presidential bid.
content: Super Bowl ads cost a fortune. So when a group backing the presidential bid of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. ran a 30-second ad for him during Sunday night’s game, the political world took notice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: On Capitol Hill, Republicans Use Bigoted Attacks Against Political Foes
description: House and Senate Republicans have denigrated fellow lawmakers, Biden administration officials and witnesses in racist ways, both in casual comments and in official settings.
content: When Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, Republican of Georgia, stood on the House floor this month to announce her proposal to censure the only Somali-born member of Congress, she said she was seeking punishment for “Representative Ilhan Omar of Somalia — I mean Minnesota.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: limelight
description: This word has appeared in 122 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word limelight has appeared in 122 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 21 in “David Letterman Ends Conspicuous Absence From ‘The Late Show’” by John Koblin:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman
title: The Politics of Betrayal Are at Work in Michigan
description: Union members and Arab voters in the state are crucial to the Democrats’ coalition.
content: Betrayal is a powerful emotion, especially at the ballot box. Voters who feel betrayed tend to act like spurned lovers, punishing the offending party even if it means electing somebody who will actually be worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Shakespeare to Hit the Road While Central Park Theater Is Closed
description: The Delacorte is being renovated, so this summer will instead bring a mobile production and then a filmed play to outdoor sites in the city’s five boroughs.
content: Free Shakespeare in the Park, one of the longtime treasures of summer in New York City, will be smaller-scale and itinerant this year because a gut renovation of the program’s Central Park home is underway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Police Announce an Arrest in the Theft of a Jackie Robinson Statue
description: The authorities say the life-size bronze statue was stolen from a park in Wichita, Kan., probably to be sold as scrap metal. The statue cannot be repaired, officials say.
content: A 45-year-old Kansas man has been charged in the theft of a life-size bronze statue of the baseball legend Jackie Robinson from a park in Wichita, Kan. The police in Wichita said on Tuesday that the motive for the crime was probably to sell the statue for scrap metal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Ukraine Claims Russia Used New Hypersonic Missile for First Time
description: Russia has not confirmed that a Zircon hypersonic missile was used. The United States says it’s looking into the claim.
content: Ukraine said it had evidence that Russia had used a new hypersonic cruise missile for the first time in an attack last week, a development that might, if confirmed, pose another challenge to the country’s already strained air defenses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Antolini, Wendy Dorr and Daniel Ramirez
title: 5 Minutes to Love New Orleans Jazz
description: Celebrate Mardi Gras by dancing in the streets.
content: Melissa A. Weber, the curator of the Hogan Archive of New Orleans Music and New Orleans Jazz at Tulane University, says the best way to experience the city’s unique jazz scene is at a second-line parade: a “moving block party” featuring a brass band.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: OpenAI Gives ChatGPT a Better ‘Memory’
description: The A.I. start-up is releasing a new version of ChatGPT that stores what users say and applies it to future chats.
content: OpenAI is giving ChatGPT a better memory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: Are You Getting Sticker Shock From Your Electric Bills? We Want to Hear About It.
description: Electricity prices have increased across the country in recent years and we want to know about your bill.
content: Upgrades to aging utility equipment and efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions have combined to drive up electricity costs across the country, with the national average increasing from one year to the next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon and Jeffrey Moyo
title: Deadliest Cholera Outbreak in Past Decade Hits Southern Africa
description: The waterborne disease has killed more than 4,000 people in seven countries over the past two years. Experts blame severe storms, a lack of vaccines, and poor water and sewer systems.
content: Sandra Mwayera wailed as her older brother slouched next to her in the back seat of a car — he had died from cholera as he waited for treatment among dozens of others outside a hospital in Zimbabwe’s capital, Harare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Why Biden Should Talk Up Economic Success
description: Persuadable Americans are noticing the good news
content: The U.S. economy has just gone through an extraordinarily successful year. Many economists (although not all of us) predicted that getting inflation under control would require a recession and an extended period of high unemployment. Instead, inflation has plunged — over the past six months the Federal Reserve’s preferred measure of underlying inflation has been running slightly below the target rate of 2 percent — even as the economy has boomed, with real G.D.P. rising 3.1 percent and employment rising by 2.9 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Who Speaks for the President? Depends on Whom You Ask.
description: The White House heralded Karine Jean-Pierre as a trailblazing press secretary. But it has increasingly relied on John Kirby, a longtime Washington hand, to spread its message.
content: On the day she was named the first Black and first openly gay White House press secretary, Karine Jean-Pierre said she hoped her appointment might inspire other people who, like her, never imagined occupying the pre-eminent role in political communications.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Biden’s Age Is a Campaign Problem, Not a Governing One
description: The president’s frailty threatens his ability to do the most important part of his job: beating Trump.
content: Last fall I found myself at a dinner party that included a former Biden administration official and a Democratic donor, and the conversation turned, naturally, to President Biden’s age and his prospects for re-election. The ex-official said that from inside the White House, where people experience the policymaking process firsthand, Biden was overwhelmingly seen as an effective leader who should run again. The donor, on the other hand, saw Biden mostly at the fund-raisers where watching the president’s meandering speeches left him terrified about the upcoming campaign. The gulf in their perceptions, I think, speaks to the fact that Biden’s age has impaired his ability to campaign much more than his ability to govern, which has created an impossible dilemma for the Democratic Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump Steps Up, Helping Biden Just When the President Needs Him
description: Donald J. Trump’s stunning statement supporting a Russian attack against “delinquent” NATO allies takes attention away from unwelcome questions about the president’s age and provides the Biden camp a useful contrast.
content: If anyone gets a thank-you note from President Biden for helping get him out of a jam in recent days, it should probably be former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Williams
title: Student Housing Has a New Mantra: Bigger Is Better
description: Off-campus complexes are getting larger, with some being home to more than 1,500 students, and being built on prime parcels of land as close to campus as possible.
content: When the Standard, an off-campus student housing complex, opened in the fall in Bloomington, Ind., welcoming its first batch of residents, it had a decidedly resort vibe. Along with the requisite pool and fitness centers, it enticed students with two pickleball courts, a dog park and a motion sports simulator. The complex even used a roommate-matching app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jon Stewart Returns to Form on ‘The Daily Show’
description: Nearly nine years after signing off as host of the late night show, Stewart returned to his seat. “We’re going to have so much we are going to talk about this year,” he said Monday.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Israel’s deadly operation to rescue two hostages.
content: Israeli special operations forces freed two hostages in the Gazan city of Rafah, the military said, as Israeli attacks killed dozens of Palestinians in the city, according to the Gazan health ministry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Haramis and Guido Taroni
title: Saying Goodbye to a Legendary Milanese Palazzo
description: An interior decorator’s family inhabited the sprawling building for six generations. Now, as they leave, he and his partner offer a final look inside.
content: SECRETS AREN’T EASILY kept at Casa degli Atellani. From his pied-à-terre on the top floor of his family’s three-story Milanese palazzo, the Italian interior designer Nicolò Castellini Baldissera, 55, who lives there with his partner of eight years, the American writer and editor Christopher Garis, 36, can see past the courtyard into his aunt Anna’s apartment. His aunt Letizia resides in a different wing. Castellini Baldissera’s father, Piero Castellini Baldissera, an architect and co-founder of the textile company C&C Milano, occupies the ground floor of the rambling 15th-century building, which was once the residence of Piero’s maternal grandparents, the influential rationalist architect Piero Portaluppi and his wife, Lia, the daughter of the industrialist Ettore Conti, who had commissioned Portaluppi to restore and renovate it — tearing down walls to combine two neo-Classical buildings — beginning in 1919. Long before that, Ludovico Sforza, the Duke of Milan, had gifted the land to his squire Giacometto di Lucia dell’Atella, whose family held onto it for generations and from whom Casa degli Atellani got its name; Leonardo da Vinci spent time there in the late 1490s while painting “The Last Supper” across the street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristina Samulewski and Vishakha Darbha
title: Feb. 13: A Holiday I Prefer Not to Celebrate
description: How a day that was intended as a feminist celebration became alienating.
content: Galentine’s Day, celebrated on Feb. 13, a day before Valentine’s Day, has been popularized as a day for women to celebrate their female friendships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Omakaseed Brings Plant-Based Sushi to the Sanctuary Hotel Near Times Square
description: Theodora brings more Mediterranean to Fort Greene, Brooklyn, Kernel provides plant-based fast-casual food and more restaurant news.
content: Exquisite traditional sushi requires vigilant ingredient shopping and meticulous technique. Removing the seafood factor, as in plant-based sushi, is a game changer. Creativity with often commonplace ingredients like carrots, lentils and coconut is required, and there are no rules. A fine example is this new omakase counter in the Sanctuary Hotel near Times Square. The setting is a library, its shelves lined with leather-bound, gilt-embossed volumes and knickknacks; the 10 seats at the polished wood counter are well upholstered with backs. It’s the work of SimpleVenue, the group that is responsible for the modestly priced, high-speed Sushi by Bou. Previously there was an Omakaseed in Plant Bar in NoMad. It closed, replaced by Trust Bae. The Omakaseed has now relocated to the hotel, where it offers an 11 course plant-based tasting for $60 and 15 courses for $100. Ryan Chon and Camdyn Healey are the chefs in charge. The items likely to be served on beautiful little plates, blocks of glass and the like will depend on seaweed “caviar,” charred king oyster mushrooms, tofu with chile crisp, smoked carrot tartare, udon noodles with miso, and shredded hearts of palm. On the drinks list are creative cocktails and more sake than wine. (Opens Wednesday).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Report Says 17 Percent of Gamers Identify as L.G.B.T.Q.
description: In its first survey of the video game industry, the advocacy group GLAAD determined that few console games include queer characters.
content: Less than 2 percent of console video games include L.G.B.T.Q. characters or story lines even though 17 percent of gamers are queer, according to GLAAD’s first survey on the industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan, Sinna Nasseri and Roger Kisby
title: At the Oscar Nominees Luncheon, He Fetched the Attention
description: In a ballroom full of A-listers in Beverly Hills, the Border collie from “Anatomy of a Fall” had the stars lining up to meet him.
content: At the annual Oscar nominees luncheon, there is always a top dog that even a ballroom full of A-listers will clamor to meet. Last year, that honor went to the “Top Gun: Maverick” producer Tom Cruise, a star so huge that the other nominees began to orbit him, biding time until they could dart in to kiss the ring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delia Falconer
title: The Opium Poppy Gets Star Billing in a New History
description: In “Smoke and Ashes,” Amitav Ghosh sources the colonial roots of a crisis.
content: Biographies of humble things that their authors claimed had “changed the world” — chronometers, salt, potatoes and even the color mauve — were a turn-of-the-21st-century publishing phenomenon. Looking back, they seem fixated on European heroes and their achievements. As Amitav Ghosh observes at the beginning of his bracing new history of the global opium trade, it’s hard to see past a Western conception of the world that “looms so large that it obscures everything else.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Dado Galdieri
title: How John Travolta Became the Star of Carnival
description: The Brazilian city of Olinda has become famous for its giant puppets during Carnival, including one made just after “Saturday Night Fever.”
content: It was near the start of one of Brazil’s most famous Carnival celebrations, in the northern seaside city of Olinda, and the town plaza was jammed with thousands of revelers. They were all awaiting their idol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Larry Taylor, Vietnam War Pilot Lauded for Daring Rescue, Dies at 81
description: His evacuation of four besieged I.S. Army Rangers was belatedly recognized last September with the Medal of Honor.
content: Larry L. Taylor, a helicopter pilot who staged a daring rescue of four U.S. Army rangers under enemy fire in the jungles of Vietnam 55 years ago, died on Jan. 28 at his home in Signal Mountain, Tenn., five months after he was belatedly awarded the Medal of Honor for his heroics. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: Mermaids and Roses: The Harlem Home of a ‘Hadestown’ Star
description: ‘I’ve been here a while,’ said Lillias White, who plays Hermes in the Tony-winning musical. ‘Hence the clutter.’
content: Lillias White may pay the rent, but her rescue dog, LaKee, is inarguably the host and star of the house, a very packed one-bedroom apartment on the top floor of a building in Harlem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Senate Republicans’ Campaign Arm Endorses Kari Lake in Arizona
description: Ms. Lake, a Trump protégé who embraced his false claims about the 2020 election and refused to concede her own loss in 2022, is running for the seat currently held by Senator Kyrsten Sinema.
content: Senate Republicans’ campaign arm on Tuesday endorsed Kari Lake in Arizona, signaling the party’s embrace of a firebrand candidate in a state central to their efforts to regain a majority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tochi Onyebuchi
title: In This Novel, a Second Civil War Reinstates Black Bondage
description: Rae Giana Rashad imagines an alternate America in her first novel, “The Blueprint.”
content: The past, however deep, is never far from the surface in Rae Giana Rashad’s debut novel, “The Blueprint.” In a near-future America, riven by Civil War II in the mid-20th century, Black Americans in select states are designated as DoS, or Descendants of Slavery. Black men are enlisted to subdue unrest within and along the borders of these states. Black women are forced into concubinage with white statesmen before being married off to Black men, a life course determined by a shadowy, faceless algorithm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Pavilonis
title: To Deepen Love, Consider Duty
description: Is it a sign of adulthood to become aware of your limitations, as well as to welcome someone to witness those limitations?
content: Susan Sontag, in her 1978 essay “Illness as Metaphor,” described “the kingdom of the ill” — in which all have dual citizenship, in addition to the kingdom of the well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Military Judge to Rule on C.I.A. Torture Program in Sept. 11 Case
description: Lawyers argued over the rare legal doctrine in an effort to dismiss the case at the start of pretrial hearings in the Sept. 11 case at Guantánamo Bay.
content: A defense lawyer asked a military judge on Monday to dismiss the Sept. 11 conspiracy charges against a Saudi prisoner who was tortured in C.I.A. custody, describing the secret overseas prison network where the man was held as part of a “vast criminal international enterprise” that trafficked in torture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mari Maeda and Yuji Oboshi
title: Flat Shoes That Look Sharp
description: The season’s most stylish pairs combine pointy toes with low heels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: A 30-Second Kennedy Ad Collides With a Decades-Long Family Legacy
description: A Super Bowl commercial that echoed a 1960 campaign ad for John F. Kennedy deepens a growing estrangement between Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and much of his family.
content: A Super Bowl advertisement promoting the presidential campaign of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. — a remake of a 1960 spot that helped put his uncle John F. Kennedy in the White House — has struck a nerve with Kennedy family members and friends, who worry that it exploits and potentially tarnishes the legacy of a storied political family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo
title: How Congress Could Bypass Republican Opposition to Funding Ukraine
description: Lawmakers in the House may resort to an arcane procedural move to force action on a foreign aid bill that Speaker Johnson has suggested he would not put to a vote.
content: Just after dawn on Tuesday, the Senate passed a $95 billion national security package with aid to Ukraine and Israel, setting up a showdown with the House, where Speaker Mike Johnson suggested he would not bring it up for a vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Wednesday Briefing: Indonesia Is Voting Today
description: Also, the ancient art of smooching.
content: The world’s third-largest democracy is today selecting not only a new president, but also members of Parliament and local representatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Preston
title: Self-Love Is Important, but We Mammals Are Stuck With Sex
description: Some female birds, reptiles and other animals can make a baby on their own. But for mammals like us, eggs and sperm need each other.
content: If Galentine’s Day had an animal mascot, it would have to be one of the species whose females can reproduce without a mate. Nearly all animals make more of themselves the traditional way, by combining eggs and sperm. But some have an alternative called parthenogenesis: no males needed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Its Forces Depleted, Myanmar Junta Says It Will Enforce a Military Draft
description: Three years after it took power in a coup, the regime appears to be on the defensive. But it remains unclear if the rebels can overthrow the military.
content: For more than three years, Myanmar’s biggest cities have remained under the unyielding grip of the military junta. But the streets of places like Yangon were uncharacteristically quiet Monday evening as a sense of fear pervaded the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Crypto PAC Jumps Into Senate Race, Opposing Katie Porter in California
description: A group called Fairshake recently revealed that it and two affiliated super PACs had amassed roughly $80 million combined in 2023. Now it’s planning to deploy some of that cash.
content: The biggest name and the biggest spender of crypto money in the 2022 election cycle is now awaiting his prison sentence for fraud and conspiracy. But new super PACs have sprouted up as the successors to the collapsed Sam Bankman-Fried empire, and they are making their first big bet of the 2024 election cycle: trying to crush Representative Katie Porter, a Democrat running in next month’s California Senate primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: The Hidden Costs of a Street Food Cart
description: Stefanos Chen, who covers the New York economy, spoke with a food vendor about the rising costs and red tape that threaten his business.
content: At Halal Plates, a food cart in Lower Manhattan, a dish of chicken over rice costs $10. That’s a 67 percent increase from 2020, the start of the coronavirus pandemic. And while consumers may gripe over the increase, the owners of Halal Plates are facing a surge in prices, too. The chicken is nearly twice as expensive as it was in 2020. The white sauce that coats it is $4 more a gallon. Even the clamshell container it’s served in has jumped in price.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: A Trump-Clinton Analogy That Could Give Biden Comfort
description: Democrats who aren’t fans of the president could come home when faced with a Trump presidency, just as Republicans returned to their party in the final days of the 2016 race.
content: There’s no precedent for a presidential candidate to face doubts as serious over age and mental acuity as President Biden faces today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward, Hwaida Saad and Adam Sella
title: Hezbollah Attack Injures 2 Israelis Amid Fresh Push to Reduce Tensions
description: Diplomats said France had presented a proposal aimed at ending the strikes and skirmishes along the border between Israel and Lebanon.
content: Hezbollah, the Lebanese militia, fired missiles into northern Israel on Tuesday that injured at least two people, emergency officials said, amid a fresh diplomatic push to end months of clashes along the border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: A Crucial Inflation Report Card
description: Investors and the White House will pore over the latest Consumer Price Index report for clues on prices — and potential interest rate cuts.
content: An S&P 500 on a five-week winning streak. A growing economy. Solid wage gains. And growing consumer and business optimism. These are the ingredients for an emerging Goldilocks scenario for the U.S. economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Police Officer Fatally Shoots Man in Queens Apartment, Officials Say
description: New York police officials said the man had pointed an “imitation gun” that seemed to be a real firearm at officers.
content: A New York City police officer on Monday fatally shot a man in a Queens apartment who officials said had pointed an “imitation gun” at officers who were responding to a 911 call reporting that shots had been fired at the building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Nicholas Fandos, Mooj Zadie, Eric Krupke, Summer Thomad, Stella Tan, Marc Georges, Rachel Quester, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
title: Why the Race to Replace George Santos Is So Close
description: The special House election in New York pits Mazi Pilip, who is running as a Republican, against Tom Suozzi, a Democrat.
content: Voters in New York are choosing the successor to George Santos, the disgraced Republican who was expelled from Congress in December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: How Hurray for the Riff Raff Learned the Power of the Present
description: Alynda Segarra used to romanticize the past. But their music evolved, and now they’re certain: “This is absolutely the right time for me to be alive, and writing songs.”
content: Almost a year after the sudden death of Alynda Segarra’s father, the sight of a Bronx-bound subway entrance made the musician cry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Denounces Trump’s Support for Russian Attack on Allies as ‘Un-American’
description: The president cited the former president’s comments in seeking to increase pressure on Speaker Mike Johnson to allow a floor vote on a $95 billion package of security aid for Ukraine and Israel approved by the Senate.
content: President Biden denounced former President Donald J. Trump on Tuesday for encouraging Russia to attack certain NATO allies, calling the comments “dumb,” “shameful,” “dangerous” and “un-American” as he implored House Republicans to defy their putative nominee and pass new security aid for Ukraine and Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: ‘Our phones will ring’: A snow plowing company prepares in New York
description: Private snow plow companies were ready to clear the streets on Tuesday as forecasts called for as much as eight inches of snow, the most in two years.
content: Jan Gautam was organizing his snow-plowing crews overnight in the way that an elite coach preps a team for a championship game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Paramount Lays Off Hundreds of Workers
description: The company, which is moving away from traditional TV, lost more than $1 billion last year at its streaming division.
content: Paramount, the owner of TV networks like Nickelodeon, MTV and Comedy Central, is laying off hundreds of employees, cutting costs as it continues its painful transition away from traditional television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Waite
title: New Romance Novels Steeped in Cozy Winter Vibes
description: If you’re craving comfort — or connection — pick up one of these books.
content: Tough times have a way of isolating a person, and while you’re living through them, sometimes you need a story that helps you back into the wider world. Romance novels do that. In their pages, you can find connection — even when it’s hard to do in real life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: Will Voters in San Francisco Go for a Different Kind of Mayor?
description: Mark Farrell, a venture capitalist who led the city for six months in 2018, wants his old job back. His chances hinge on how far the liberal city has moved toward the center.
content: Famously liberal San Francisco is irritable these days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Egner
title: ‘Now Where Was I?’ Jon Stewart Is Back in His Old ‘Daily Show’ Seat
description: On Monday night, the longtime host of the Comedy Central news satire kicked off his new tenure in classic form.
content: Jon Stewart returned on Monday night as host of “The Daily Show,” the Comedy Central news satire he turned into a cultural force before leaving in August 2015. It was the beginning of a plan, announced in January, that will bring Stewart back to the show on Mondays through the presidential election. He will also serve as an executive producer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya S. Cade
title: Pushing for Recognition Took Billy Dee Williams to the Stratosphere
description: His charming memoir “What Have We Here?” traces the path from a Harlem childhood to “Star Wars,” while lamenting the roles that never came his way.
content: My first awareness of Billy Dee Williams was the stuff of hushed beauty parlor conversation I was too young to appreciate. “After all these years he’s still fine,” elders whispered in my periphery as they flipped through an interview in an Ebony magazine that was treated as an heirloom. His piercing gaze leaped out across time. “That’s our Billy!” another giggled.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Slushy, Snowy, Icy Mix
description: The first significant snowstorm of the season created a wintry scene across the Northeast.
content: A nor’easter disrupted daily life across the Northeast on Tuesday, upending school and work commutes, as rain turned to a slushy mix and then to snow in many regions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Chen
title: Wanted: True Love. Reward: $100,000.
description: Two men posted “dating bounties” on the internet worth thousands as an incentive for people to help them find love.
content: For most of Mati Roy’s life, dating was far down on his list of priorities. Though he halfheartedly tried dating apps, and would have welcomed a relationship if it developed naturally, pursuing love didn’t seem worth the effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Lunar New Year Hot Pot
description: Do you celebrate Lunar New Year? How?
content: Lunar New Year, also known as Chinese New Year, fell on Feb. 10 this year, and ushered in the Year of the Dragon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Sloss
title: 5 Presidential Libraries That Offer Culture, History and ‘Labs of Democracy’
description: With museums, special exhibitions and unique events, presidential libraries across the country are designed as destinations for everyone — not just scholars or academics.
content: As repositories of valuable historical documents and other records, U.S. presidential libraries have long been important destinations for scholars. But you don’t have to be an academic or even a history buff to appreciate these destinations, as many increasingly offer museums, special exhibitions and unique programming — ranging from interactive situation room experiences to musical performances — to the general public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: C.D.C. Considers Ending 5-Day Isolation Period for Covid
description: Americans may be advised that it’s safe to return to regular routines after one day without a fever.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is considering loosening its recommendations regarding how long people should isolate after testing positive for the coronavirus, another reflection of changing attitudes and norms as the pandemic recedes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Haley’s Hard-Line Immigration Record Runs Counter to Trump’s Attacks
description: Donald Trump has accused Nikki Haley of siding with Democrats on the border. In South Carolina, friends and foes alike do not recognize that portrait of the former governor.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump and his allies have spent weeks painting Nikki Haley as a bleeding heart on immigration as he seeks to dispatch her as his last remaining rival for the 2024 Republican nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Before Houston Megachurch Shooting, a Series of Warning Signs
description: A woman who opened fire at Lakewood Church engaged in “antisemitic rants” and kept guns in the house even after being involuntarily hospitalized for mental illness, her mother-in-law said.
content: Those who knew the woman who opened fire on Sunday with an AR-15 rifle inside Lakewood Church in Houston said the warning signs had been flashing, off and on, for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Nikki Haley Feels the Love in Her South Carolina Hometown
description: Ms. Haley has traveled throughout the state trying to cut into former President Donald J. Trump’s lead. But even with a friendly audience, her uphill battle to win votes remained clear.
content: Nearly a year after Nikki Haley, a former governor of South Carolina, released a video announcing her presidential campaign, she returned to the place where it was shot: her hometown of Bamberg, S.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Austin Is Released From the Hospital and Will Return to Work
description: The defense secretary, who was hospitalized in January for complications from prostate cancer surgery, underwent a nonsurgical procedure to address a bladder issue, doctors said.
content: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III was released from the hospital on Tuesday, the Pentagon said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel and Marlise Simons
title: South Africa Asks Top U.N. Court to Act Against Israel’s Plans for Rafah
description: The International Court of Justice in The Hague, which last month ordered Israel to ensure its actions in Gaza would not lead to genocide, is required to regard the new request as a matter of priority.
content: With Israel continuing to warn that it plans a ground invasion of Rafah, the southernmost city in Gaza, South Africa has asked the International Court of Justice in The Hague to issue new constraints on Israel’s military offensive to prevent genocide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: ‘Izzard Hamlet New York’ Review: A Solo Show That’s More Noble Than Wise
description: Eddie Izzard is a wildly witty ad-libber, but a play straitjackets this gift — especially in this new staging that is short of ideas.
content: To laugh, or not to laugh? That is the question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Jeffrey Wright: Hiding in Plain Sight in Our Favorite Characters
description: The veteran has played everything from an artist to a general to a professor, the role in “American Fiction” that finally landed him an Oscar nomination.
content: A couple of years ago, Jeffrey Wright got an email from the screenwriter Cord Jefferson, who was preparing to direct his first film. Jefferson wanted Wright — a cerebral actor known for his commanding, indelible presence even in supporting roles — to star in “American Fiction,” his adaptation of Percival Everett’s mordant 2001 novel, “Erasure.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: France Imposes Sanctions on West Bank Settlers, Joining the U.S. and Britain.
description: The French foreign ministry said it had banned 28 settlers from entering France or any of its territories, calling on Israel’s government to pursue legal action against them.
content: France imposed sanctions on dozens of Israeli settlers in the occupied West Bank on Tuesday, accusing them of committing acts of violence against Palestinians. It was one of the largest rounds of penalties levied against Israelis in the West Bank to date and follows Britain and U.S. restrictions imposed on four settlers this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maura Cheeks
title: What if Federal Reparations Weren’t a Fiction?
description: Federal reparations would help redress both the grievances of American history and the racial inequities that still define the present.
content: In my debut novel, a family retraces their lineage in order to be eligible for the nation’s first federal reparations program for Black Americans. When I was selling my novel in 2021, it was pitched to publishers as “speculative fiction, but only slightly.” I hadn’t specifically identified that genre, but I could see how it made sense: Up to that point, only one U.S. city, Evanston, Ill., had actually issued reparations in the form of housing grants. The idea that the United States could ever collectively support a national reparations policy for Black people seemed, well, the stuff of fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: N.Y.C. Revived Remote Schooling for a Day. It Was a Mess.
description: The chancellor said the “school system is more than prepared.” But when it was time to log on, many students could not.
content: New York City public schools on Tuesday embarked on their first major experiment with remote learning since the coronavirus pandemic. More than 900,000 students were asked to join virtual classes during the winter storm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Davis
title: Listening to Music Is Better When It’s a Conversation Among Friends
description: At group listening sessions, everybody gets a turn to speak by choosing a song.
content: If you are the type of person who bides your time waiting for any conversation to pivot to music, who scrabbles through the dollar-record bins of junk shops or mudlarks around the streaming playlists of your favorite musicians hunting for rarities, you might be a Golden Ear. You almost certainly love music, but odds are, you are listening to it alone. The Golden Ears are devoted to listening to music together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Only Biden and M.B.S. Can Redirect the Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
description: What the president and the Saudi crown prince need to do.
content: One of the most unexpected developments in the Israel-Hamas war is the emergence of a powerful alignment of interests and incentives for Israel, the Palestinians, America and Saudi Arabia to all get behind a pathway to a Palestinian state that can live in peace alongside Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Prevailing on Ukraine Funding, McConnell Took Political Hits
description: The minority leader’s handling of the border and foreign aid legislation drew scorching criticism from far-right Republicans, though he scored a legislative win on an issue he regards as existential and part of his legacy.
content: Senator Mitch McConnell put his standing on the line in aggressively pursuing military assistance for Ukraine over deep Republican resistance, and he achieved the outcome he wanted: a strong Senate vote to bolster embattled U.S. allies at a critical moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Josephs
title: ‘The Vince Staples Show’ Is Part Art House, Part ‘Home Improvement’
description: The hip-hop star’s wit has long shone in his critically acclaimed music and on social media. Now, it is the center of his new Netflix sitcom.
content: Vince Staples is not someone you would describe as “excitable.” During a recent conversation about his new Netflix sitcom, “The Vince Staples Show,” his deliberate drawl remained steady throughout. But his clear pride in the series, out Thursday, broke through his placid exterior a few times, such as when he talked about the cameo by the high-living rapper Rick Ross or the show’s Swedish film influences. He also knows that the mere fact of its existence is exceptional.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Karoun Demirjian
title: Ukraine Aid Bill Faces Hurdles in the House Amid G.O.P. Opposition
description: Speaker Mike Johnson has indicated he won’t put the Senate legislation to a vote in the House, leaving proponents scrambling to find a path to passage.
content: A buzz saw of Republican opposition in the House is threatening to kill the $95 billion aid package for Ukraine and Israel that the Senate overwhelmingly passed early Tuesday, leaving proponents of the emergency aid legislation scrounging for unorthodox ways to push the bill over the finish line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: New England Prepares for as Much as a Foot of Snow
description: While the National Weather Service said forecasts in some areas remained “far from certain,” it was predicting that some parts of the region could see as much as a foot of snow.
content: Officials across New England were preparing on Tuesday for a major nor’easter to hit the region, closing schools and warning residents across Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Connecticut to stay off roads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: They’re Starting a New York ‘Housing League.’ NIMBYs Not Allowed.
description: Brooklyn’s borough president and a Manhattan councilman are forming a club of politicians who embrace using development to ease New York City’s housing crisis.
content: A housing crisis threatens New York City? A pair of politicians believe they have an answer: a new “league” of officials like themselves who want to welcome development, including development of market-rate apartments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: ‘Women for Nikki’ Coalition Courts Group It Sees Trump Putting Off
description: The coalition, which includes more than 4,500 members in all 50 states, aims to help Nikki Haley attract suburban women and keep her campaign alive.
content: As Nikki Haley enters the final stretch of the Republican primary in South Carolina on Feb. 24, her presidential campaign on Tuesday unveiled a new national coalition aimed at making inroads with one group in particular: suburban women turned off by former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Bearak
title: U.S. Gas Producers Are Racing to Sell to Asia. And Mexico Is Key.
description: By next year, American natural gas will start flowing across Mexico to a major export terminal on the Pacific, reflecting a global energy landscape transformed by U.S. dominance in gas.
content: ​As soon as next year, the United States’ fossil fuel industry will gain its first foothold on a valuable shortcut to sell natural gas to Asia. The shortcut goes straight through Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Yu
title: These Grandmas Are Going to the Oscars
description: In the documentary short “Nǎi Nai & Wài Pó,” Sean Wang chronicles the inner lives of his grandmothers. Now, the film is nominated for an Academy Award.
content: After he moved back home to the Bay Area in 2021, weighing a move to Los Angeles amid the pandemic, the filmmaker Sean Wang would often spend time with his two grandmothers. Yi Yan Fuei, his 96-year-old Nǎi Nai (paternal grandmother), and Chang Li Hua, his 86-year-old Wài Pó (maternal grandmother), live in the same house together, and Wang quickly began to observe two versions of them. There they were, enmeshed in the quiet rhythms of their daily lives — folding laundry, peeling fruit, napping in their shared bed. Then, Wang, 29, would intrude, coaxing out their playful sides: receiving a slap on the butt or spurring a dance session.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: SpaceX Postpones Launch of Intuitive Machines Moon Mission
description: The latest flight of a private company attempting to carry NASA payloads to the lunar surface was delayed to Thursday morning.
content: Another month, another try at the moon — but not on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: 8 Crush Songs for Valentine’s Day
description: Hear tracks by Frank Ocean, Alicia Keys and of course, the Jets.
content: Tomorrow is Valentine’s Day, but for today’s playlist I wanted to give you something more specific than a collection of love songs. (For one thing, that mix would be approximately three billion tracks long.) Here, instead, is a playlist of crush songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘The Space Race’ Review: Why Was NASA So White?
description: The days of shooting for the stars, interpreted through the stories of people of color whose aspirations were repeatedly thwarted.
content: The story of man’s foray into space is a thrilling one, encompassing war, technological innovation and the power of imagination. The story of the Black man’s foray into space — the subject of the documentary “The Space Race” — comprises a different set of milestones. For African Americans who dreamed of traveling beyond the earth’s atmosphere, the barriers weren’t just physical or scientific, but also social and political.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy, Eliza Fawcett and Olivia Bensimon
title: New York Gets Enough Snow to Dig, not Despise
description: The storm brought the highest snowfall total to Central Park in over two years, but less than had been feared.
content: Worrisome forecasts and technical glitches with remote school gave way to sunshine in New York City by Tuesday afternoon, as the storm moved out of the area without as much drama as initially feared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: School Districts From Philadelphia to Boston Announce Closures and Delays
description: Major school systems in the Northeast and New England are either canceling classes or going virtual on Tuesday because of the storm.
content: As cities in the Northeast and New England prepared for what might be a sweeping winter storm on Tuesday, dozens of school systems in a handful of states canceled classes, pulled the plug on after-school activities and modified their schedules in other ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Gives Prosecutors a Week to Respond in Trump Immunity Case
description: The schedule the justices set was not particularly speedy, though nothing prevents the special counsel from filing sooner than the court’s Feb. 20 deadline.
content: The Supreme Court on Tuesday gave Jack Smith, the special counsel prosecuting former President Donald J. Trump, a week to respond to Mr. Trump’s emergency application asking the justices to halt an appeals court’s ruling that rejected his claim that he is absolutely immune from criminal charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Performance by Maestro With Russian Ties Is Canceled in Vienna
description: A Teodor Currentzis concert at the Wiener Festwochen was canceled after the Ukrainian conductor Oksana Lyniv, also on the program, raised concerns about his ties to Russia.
content: When the Wiener Festwochen, a prestigious festival that brings leading international artists to Vienna, announced this spring’s lineup, the backlash was swift and fierce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: How Much Advil Is Too Much?
description: Ibuprofen can be a blessing for those with aches and pains, but overdoing it poses serious risks.
content: Q: I take Advil pretty regularly for pain, but how can I tell if I’m taking more than is safe?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Via Verde Was Built to Be a Model for Public Housing. Did It Succeed?
description: Twelve years after the first residents of the South Bronx development moved in, The Times’s architecture critic looks at how it has fared.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at Via Verde, which was planned as a model of beautiful, sustainable subsidized housing in the South Bronx, through the eyes of The New York Times’s architecture critic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: A Key Inflation Gauge Came In Hotter Than Expected Last Month
description: Overall prices cooled slightly from a year earlier, but the report included worrying signs for the Federal Reserve.
content: Inflation cooled less than expected in January and showed worrying staying power after volatile food and fuel costs were stripped out — a reminder that bringing price increases under control remains a fraught, bumpy process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Covid Shots for Children
description: Much of the world has decided that most young children don’t need to receive Covid booster shots. The U.S. is an outlier.
content: Much of the world has decided that most young children do not need to receive Covid booster shots. It’s true in Britain, France, Japan and Australia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Man Dies in First Known Fatal Case of Alaskapox
description: Alaska state health officials said that a man died last month of the virus, which occurs mostly in small mammals and causes lesions. There have been seven reported human cases since 2015.
content: An Alaska man died last month of Alaskapox, a rare virus that occurs mostly in small mammals and can cause skin lesions, according to state health officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Models Wanted: Must Be Over 40
description: A fashion label dares to cast middle-aged (and up) women in a runway show.
content: Over the last few weeks, Batsheva Hay has stopped women outside a dance studio, on the subway and inside a grocery store. She has slid into strangers’ DMs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: Is That Polar Bear Getting Enough to Eat? Try a Collar With a Camera.
description: Scientists collected video from 20 bears during ice-free months to understand whether the animals can survive longer periods on land in a warming world.
content: Climate change is stretching the length of time parts of the Far North go without sea ice, which polar bears rely on to hunt their preferred prey: blubbery, calorie-rich seals. When the ice melts in summer, the bears move onto land and face two options. They can rest and slow down to a state approaching hibernation, or they can forage for alternative food like berries, bird eggs and small land animals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: David Bouley, Influential New York Chef, Dies at 70
description: At restaurants like Montrachet and Bouley, he channeled French nouvelle cuisine to create the New American style.
content: David Bouley, the American chef who first translated French nouvelle cuisine into the New American style that shaped modern high-end cooking, died on Monday at his home in Kent, Conn. He was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Millan Verma
title: Meet Flagboy Giz, a Rapper Uniting New Orleans Cultural Traditions
description: The 37-year-old artist is a Black Masking Indian who sews his own colorful suits. His blending those practices with rap music has made him one of the city’s most in-demand performers.
content: In his cluttered two-room apartment in Gentilly, a small neighborhood just south of Lake Pontchartrain in New Orleans, Flagboy Giz used dental floss to thread brightly colored beads through black gym shoes on a stormy February afternoon. His desk held a humble recording setup — a microphone, laptop and two speakers. An assemblage of neon feathers and phosphorescent beads burst out of drawers and scattered across the floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marina Harss
title: Jean Butler Choreographs the Past and Future of Irish Dance
description: In “What We Hold” at the Irish Arts Center, the “Riverdance” star turned contemporary choreographer returns to Irish dance with an inquiring lens.
content: Halfway through Jean Butler’s “What We Hold,” the audience is invited to sit at a long table surrounded by 50 chairs, as if at a wedding banquet. Instead of place settings, three dancers are before them. As the audience settles in, voices begin to float through the room, like snatches of lost conversations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek, Ana Swanson and Thomas Ekström
title: This Arctic Circle Town Expected a Green Energy Boom. Then Came Bidenomics.
description: Generous subsidies are helping the United States steal green industries from Europe, as countries race to secure the energy supplies of the future.
content: In Mo i Rana, a small Norwegian industrial town on the cusp of the Arctic Circle, a cavernous gray factory sits empty and unfinished in the snowy twilight — a monument to unfulfilled economic hope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: Stocks Sink as Stubborn Inflation Resets Fed Rate Forecasts
description: A hotter-than-expected inflation report led investors to push out their expectations for Federal Reserve rate cuts until later in the year.
content: Stocks tumbled on Tuesday after a hotter-than-expected inflation report pushed investors to rethink bets on how soon the Federal Reserve will take the brakes off the economy and cut interest rates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: As U.S. Weighs Aid, Ukraine Turns to European Allies for Support
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky is expected to seek more military assistance in Berlin, Paris and possibly London.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky is redoubling his diplomatic outreach to Europe in the hopes of starting to fill the void left by months of American indecision, as the debate over providing renewed military assistance for Ukraine continues to play out in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Republicans Are Trying Again to Impeach Mayorkas
description: Also, the U.S. may loosen its Covid isolation guidance. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: The House will vote tonight for the second time on whether to impeach Alejandro Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, on charges of willfully refusing to enforce border laws. Last week, Republicans suffered a stunning embarrassment when their yearlong push to impeach him failed on its first attempt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Big Burden of Migrant Influx Strains Denver
description: The city has marshaled resources for the new arrivals, but after Congress rejected a deal aimed at slowing the flow of migrants, its support system is starting to buckle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Guerrero and Landon Nordeman
title: Inside LaQuan Smith’s New York Fashion Week Bash
description: The designer drew hundreds of people to his after-party, an event known for spectacles at every turn.
content: As an impending snowstorm loomed over New York City late Monday night, the bouncers at the Box filtered through a steady stream of musicians, models and internet personalities in fur coats (or no coat at all) for the designer LaQuan Smith’s after-party.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Museums Handle Cultural Artifacts
description: Responses to a guest essay about stolen artifacts and replicas. Also: President Biden’s climate leadership; giving voters choices; free SAT tutoring.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Easy Cleanup Is Romantic
description: Sheet-pan Cajun salmon, brown butter orzo with butternut squash and gochujang-glazed eggplant are one-pan and wonderful.
content: Should I be embarrassed by the fact I like Valentine’s Day? Probably? But I do. I like everything chocolate, I think flowers are charming, I have nothing against a nice glass of wine and I melt when my children present me with homemade cards scribbled with their sweet handwriting. If you welcome an opportunity to cook a special meal for your partner or to put out an amazing spread for your friends, then I’m offering up Valentine’s Day for your consideration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Steve Scalise Returns to Capitol After Cancer Treatment, Noting ‘Votes Are Tight’
description: The first attempt to impeach the homeland security secretary fell short by one vote, when he was absent from Washington.
content: Representative Steve Scalise of Louisiana, the majority leader, returned to the Capitol on Tuesday following a six-week absence during which he received a stem-cell transplant as part of his treatment for blood cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Mix Drinks
description: Peter Gordon has the right attitude in today’s crossword puzzle.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Willa Glickman
title: The Labor Movement Hasn’t Taken Off. A New Book Explains Why.
description: “The Hammer” offers portraits of organizing efforts from around the country at a time when the future of union power has reached an inflection point.
content: In 2022, after being elected president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the biggest federation of unions in the United States, Liz Shuler stood before a crowd of union officials gathered in a large ballroom in Philadelphia and announced a new goal: “In the next 10 years, we will organize and grow our movement by more than one million people!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: You Might Not Like What Jon Stewart Has to Tell You
description: The comedian returned to “The Daily Show,” claiming the prerogative to tell his audience jokes they don’t want to hear.
content: “Why am I back?” asked Jon Stewart, returning to “The Daily Show” chair as Monday night host after leaving the program in 2015. It was a fair question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell and Matthew Eadie
title: Bummed in Boston: No School, No Snow
description: “I think most people understand that these things happen,” said a spokesman for the city’s school district, which canceled classes based on a forecast that didn’t materialize.
content: Despite predictions, Boston was left mostly snowless on Tuesday. Few residents seemed upset to be spared, except for the city’s children — robbed of any actual snow on a snow day — and their working parents, who were forced to make alternate plans for child care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson and Melonyce McAfee
title: 100 Small Acts of Love
description: New York Times readers shared how they show affection on Valentine’s Day and every other day.
content: New York Times readers shared how they show affection on Valentine’s Day and every other day.

title: A Tunnel Offers Clues to How Hamas Uses Gaza’s Hospitals
description: New evidence shows Hamas operated under Al-Shifa Hospital but falls short of proving Israel’s early claims that there was a command center there.

description: The 1,200-square-foot home uses a fraction of the energy consumed by a traditional house.

description: ‘I’ve been here a while,’ said Ms. White, who plays Hermes in the Tony-winning musical through March. ‘Hence the clutter.’

title: In Scorning Trump’s Remarks, Biden Urges House to Pass Ukraine Aid Bill
description: During remarks on the $95 billion Ukraine and Israel aid package, President Biden condemned former President Donald J. Trump for encouraging Russia to attack some NATO members.
content: During remarks on the $95 billion Ukraine and Israel aid package, President Biden condemned former President Donald J. Trump for encouraging Russia to attack some NATO members.

author: By Jack Nicas and Nikolay Nikolov
title: The Star of This Carnival Is a Giant John Travolta Puppet
description: At the start of one of Brazil’s most famous Carnival celebrations, the town of Olinda was jammed with thousands of revelers. They were all awaiting the arrival of their idol: a 12-foot puppet of John Travolta.
content: At the start of one of Brazil’s most famous Carnival celebrations, the town of Olinda was jammed with thousands of revelers. They were all awaiting the arrival of their idol: a 12-foot puppet of John Travolta.
